Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2013 06:44PM lola12 wrote: I removed my ovaries due to the fact that I wanted to be on an AI and could not unless I was postmenopausal. I didnt plan on having any other children, so it was a no brainer for me. I was ER+ and the ovaries produces a small amount of estrogen, so I wanted them gone.  The hotflashes were the only true problem for me. And, one year later they are much less.  I say do what you can. I was out of work for 3 days and I really dont regret it.

Posts.Content: lola12 wrote: Does anyones oncologist NOT use oncotype dx in determining chemo. I have stage 1, node negetive but multifocal .3mm, .6mm and 1.7cm mostly lobular, little ductal. My local doc said chemo no matter what the oncotypes says and my doc in NYC says if oncotype is low, chemo will not respond and is not needed. Do most doctors use oncotype? One doc said that lobular is usually low oncotype because it responds better to hormone therapy. Any experience with this? THanks, Lola Lola Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Use of Oncotype lola12 kira1234

Posts.Content: lola12 wrote: Hi all, I sure can use some input. Here is what I know so far, 1.4 cm ILC er/pr pos, her2 neg, brca neg. My doctors feel this was caught very early since I had an intraductal papilloma lumpectomy in Jan 2010 with benign biopsy as well as mri and ultrasound. The area of ILC was noticed in Jan but it was thought to be a fibroadenoma and was watched. I have lumpectomy and SNB next week. I feel positive about doing what I need to do and going on with my life. I understand that radiation and possibly chemo is what I need to do. My spouse on the other hand is in deep depression. Thinking I will die soon. My spouse is in a total hold your breathe, sleeping alot depression and I dont know how to deal with it. Am I missing something, is there a reason why I should not be thankful and positive. I know chemo wont be fun. I know I will lose my hair. But I feel I will be ok after  treatment and will be monitored closely for any future problems. Should I start worrying too? Lola Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Feelings lola12 hopefulhealing

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2018 04:54AM lola12 wrote: Flag, I am glad your doctor gave you something to sleep. Once you get your MRI results, you will be ready to formulate a plan. Did your doctor suggest getting an oncotype done? Yes, I am 8 years cancer free, mammogram was good- this will be you too. It is hard to believe in those dark moments, but your cancer is small and treatable. Lola
Posts.Title: Diagnosed- awaiting test results flag6818 lola12

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2018 07:25PM lola12 wrote: Hi, Truly, the waiting is the worst part of the process, but once you get a plan of attack in place, you will find strength. I had a 1.7cm mass and was grade 1 just like you. Today, I had a clean mammogram and I am now celebrating my 8th year cancer free. This am, I felt like you. My anxiety was high, freaking out and predicting the very worst result in my head. Are you waiting to see your oncologist or surgeon next? Do you feel you need something to calm your anxiety for a short time? I did. Are there any questions that I can answer based on my experience? Lola
Posts.Title: Diagnosed- awaiting test results flag6818 lola12

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2018 03:39PM lola12 wrote: Hi Karen, I also can fall into the trap of letting fear of recurrence stop me from living my life. I was diagnosed 8 years ago and a few years back I decided to only let myself worry a few days before my mammogram. I even put a note in my calendar and allow myself the time to let that worry out. Tomorrow is my 8th year mammogram and it is anxiety time. In fact, during this anxiety time each year, I also visit this message board. But, I think as time goes by, it allows us to put worry in perspective and in it's place. I am down to scan anxiety, you will be too. My doctor termed this deep worry as medical PTSD. This worsens without help. I needed medication for a while. But, truly, time heals a lot of things. For now, get the help. Lola.

I know there are so many false positives with scans and my oncologist never suggested one. Lola Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: lola12 wrote: Hi,  My mothers breast has been very painful in 3 different areas. So, painful she could not even be hugged! Yesterday we went to the doctors office. No lumps felt, but the doctor wanted to do an ultrasound anyway. Today, my mother went for the ultrasound and they told her that something did show up. Even though it would be extremely painful, they urged my mother to let them take a mammogram. They said the area has been on her past mammograms but never changed. She is patiently waiting for the doctor to call with results.   Should we insist on getting a biopsy if they opt to wait and recheck in 6 months. Does any of this make sense? Lola  Lola Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Oh no... lola12 lola12

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2012 05:42AM lola12 wrote: Thank you Mdg and Bessie. My mother does not understand things very well, and I am trying to help. I am just two years  from having my own mastectomy.   The doctor told her that the area was on her last two mammograms. No one ever said anything to her about it. The size is 6mm. The ultrasound saw it and comparing it to her recent and past mammogram it has not changed. My question is to ask why they now want to biopsy it? She doesnt know the Birad number. Just that the size has not changed, but they want to biopsy it.   I had ILC, which I know is sneaky. But, if the size didnt change, why suggest biopsy? Thanks! Lola

Posts.Content: May 7, 2019 10:40AM lola12 wrote: Thankfully, it went well. 9 years cancer free :) Thank you for all the advice. I called and explained my anxiety to the staff and they said come in at 1:30 and the radiologist will read it immediately. I am breathing again.
Posts.Title: Dread and Anxiety over yearly Mammogram lola12 lola12

Posts.Content: lola12 wrote: I had a unilateral mastectomy almost 9 years ago for stage 1A cancer and each year I have such extreme anxiety over getting a mammogram. It almost stalls my life, I cant sleep, and just go through the motions of life until I get my result. Am I the only one? How do you cope. I am due and cant decide to take time off work and just get it done or to wait until my day off next week. I feel like my entire body is on alert and I am trying to figure out how to handle this. I know my mammograms have been fine, I know recurrence rate is low for my stage, but I just cannot get a grip on this. Any suggestions? Lola Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: lola12 wrote: I have had extremely painful breasts and went to my ob-gyn. No lumps felt, but she wanted me to get an ultrasound. I did and a spot was found. 6mm. They asked if I can handle the pain of a mammogram and i did. Apparently, this 6mm area was seen on the last two years of mammograms.  I got a call from my doctor telling me we needed to biopsy it. Why, if this area was on my last two mammograms and havent changed in size? Do I assume it is birad 5? Thanks, Lola  Lola Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: biopsy or no biopsy lola12 rosie83

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2018 03:44PM lola12 wrote: I am in favor of telling them the truth. We want to shield our children from worry, but part of life is to love and support and to stand beside family at good and bad times. Tell them the odds are in your favor, but you want them to be aware of the situation. It strengthens relationships.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2010 04:22PM lola12 wrote: I had nipple discharge a while back and the cytology even came back abnormal. I had a procedure called ductoscopy, like a coloscopy to the breast duct, and they found a intraductal papilloma..totally benign. I would not jump the gun thinking its cancer. There are many reasons. Lucky me, 8 months later, just last week i was diagnosed with ILC thanks to my 6 month follow up from the papilloma its looking small and early. only 1.2cm at widest margin.
